text: I actually began running when I was 12
years old because I want to make the
field hockey team in my high school and
my dad encouraging me to run a mile a
day there was a skinny little insecure
kid and when I ran this mile a day I not
only made the field hockey team but I
became so empowered I met this guy who
was helping to coach the Syracuse
University men's cross country team his
name was Arnie Briggs I told him I
wanted to run the Boston Marathon and he
said without missing a beat a woman
can't run the Boston Marathon women
themselves didn't understand that they
had the capability they were afraid of
all the old myths of getting a big leg
and growing a mustache and your uterus
falling out we argued and he said if you
showed me in practice that you could run
the Boston distance 26 miles 385 yards
I'd be the first person to take you one
day we actually ran 31 miles to his word
he helped me sign up for the race he
said there's nothing about gender in the
rulebook and there's nothing about
gender on the entry form I said well
okay so I paid my $2.00 I signed my name
with my initials and the entry form
obviously went into Boston and the
Boston officials thought it was a guy
and they awarded me number 261 the
morning of the Boston Marathon was
incredible it was sleeping and snowing
with a terrible headwind I had on this
really darling shorts and top that Betty
wanted to show to show off but it was so
cold I wasn't going to take off my heavy
gray warm-up suit and the officials
pushed us into a starting pen and
everybody looking alike in these baggy
warm-up suits they couldn't tell me from
one of the guys and when I got into the
pen I said to Ernie I said well you're
right there's no problem and he said I
told you there'd be no problem
the gun went off and down the street we
went the first couple of miles were
great and the press truck came by us on
the outside and they went crazy you know
a girls in the race she's wearing pip
numbers and they were shooting and we
were kind of waving to them because it
was a just a flash media moment when all
of a sudden behind me I heard leather
shoes clearly not like running shoes and
suddenly I saw this man he was ferocious
looking and I was so frightened he
grabbed me by the shoulders and he spun
me back like that and tried to rip off
my bib number and he screamed get the
hell out of my race and give me those
numbers I was so terrified and scared
but my boyfriend came running and hit
the official and sent him flying out of
the race and my little coach said run
like hell and down the street we went
someplace about Heartbreak Hill which is
a 21 miles in the Boston Marathon the
anger left me because you know you can't
run long and stay angry I turned to my
coach and I said I have to finish the
race even if I have to finish it on my
hands and my knees because of I don't
finish the race nobody's gonna believe
that women can do this nobody's gonna
believe that women should be here
when I finished the race I felt like I
had a life plan I had a goal and a real
purpose to achieve and I felt absolutely
fulfilled also because I had I'd run my
first marathon under the most incredibly
difficult conditions and I knew after
that nothing was going to be is hard we
wound up organizing 400 races in 27
countries and used the data and
statistics from those events to lobby
the International Olympic Committee and
got the women's marathon into the
Olympic Games in 1984 we know if we can
empower women they can do anything and
it's sometimes the simplest thing
putting one foot in front of the other
will do that
